questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following conditions does not involve the bronchus?
questions.explanation:
Emphysema does not involve the bronchus, it involves the acinus. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) includes both emphysema and chronic bronchitis. Other obstructive lung diseases include: • Bronchial asthma - characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway 
hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli • Bronchiectasis - destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue by chronic necrotizing infections

Question 2: A patient with severe emphysema underwent lung volume reduction surgery. The resected 
specimen is shown below. What type of emphysema is this?
questions.explanation:
The given gross image is characteristic of centriacinar emphysema. 1094 
Sold by @itachibot In paraseptal emphysema subpleural spaces are mainly affected (shown below). 1095 
Sold by @itachibot In panacinar emphysema all air spaces within acini are evenly enlarged (shown below).

questions.question:
Question 3: 1084 
Sold by @itachibot In patients with COPD, the emphysematous damage is most likely to involve which of the 
following structures?
questions.explanation:
Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) usually have centriacinar 
emphysema which involves respiratory bronchioles. Emphysema is classified into four major types: • Centriacinar • Panacinar • Paraseptal • Irregular 1096 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and 
wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a 
smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the 
following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
questions.explanation:
The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire 
acinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema. It is caused due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency. In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the 
respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. It occurs commonly in the lower zones and in 
the anterior margins of the lung and is most severe at the bases. The image below shows panacinar emphysema.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 25-year-old man is being evaluated for dyspnea and cough for 2 months. He is not a 
smoker. Workup revealed emphysematous changes at lung bases. He reports that his father 
and uncles were diagnosed with liver failure and lung disease at relatively young ages. Where 1085 
Sold by @itachibot is the gene encoding the defective protein located?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of 1-antitrypsin deficiency. The 1-antitrypsin is encoded by the 
proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14. 1-AT is a polymorphic gene located on chromosome 14. It is part of a larger family of structurally 
unique serine protease inhibitors, referred to as serpins. The most common clinically significant 
mutation in 1-antitrypsin deficiency is PiZZ. 1-antitrypsin, normally present in serum, tissue fluids, and macrophages is a major inhibitor of 
proteases (particularly elastase) secreted by neutrophils during inflammation. The absence of 1- 
antitrypsin activity results in excessive digestion of elastic tissue by elastase. Patients with 1-antitrypsin deficiency have a markedly increased tendency to develop panacinar 
emphysema.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 55-year-old man was brought to the ED with fever, cough with expectoration, and difficulty 
in breathing for 1 day. He is a chronic smoker and he has had similar progressive symptoms 
for the last 4 years. Past PFT findings showed reduced FEV1 and increased RV with normal 
diffusion capacity. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario gives a picture of acute exacerbation of COPD. The most common 
bacterial cause of acute COPD exacerbation is Haemophilus influenzae. Moraxella is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.

questions.question:
Question 8: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and 
chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy 
reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows 
in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma. Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness 
to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction 
to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are 
less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants. Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma: • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or 
allergic disease • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows: • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10 • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or 
bronchioles 1099 
Sold by @itachibot • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells • Numerous eosinophils Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and 
other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.question:
Question 9: A resected specimen of a lung is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? 1087 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image above shows markedly distended bronchi involving the middle and lower lobe of the 
lung which is seen in bronchiectasis. Bronchiectasis is a suppurative lung disease with abnormal and irreversible dilatation of the 
bronchi. It is an end-stage condition of various diseases that result in destruction of the bronchial 
wall and its surrounding supporting tissues. The normal clearing mechanisms are impaired, either due to congenital causes or due to bronchial 
obstruction. This results in pooling of secretions, secondary infection, and inflammation, often 
with necrosis, fibrosis, and eventually cystic dilation of airways up to four times the normal size. Note: Kartagener syndrome is a primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of 
situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

questions.question:
Question 10: Transbronchial biopsy from a patient showed the following microscopic finding. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image above shows alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies). This is 
characteristically seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP). Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, 
alveoli, and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. 1100 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical presentation of COP is the development of nonspecific systemic and respiratory 
symptoms. It is associated with filling of the lung alveoli that is visible on a chest X-ray as patchy 
unilateral or bilateral consolidation. COP was previously known as bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

questions.question: Question 11: What is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world?
questions.explanation:
Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world. Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica (e.g., quartz). Individuals involved with the 
concrete work, sandblasting, stone carvers, and jewelers using chalk molds are at high risk. Pneumoconioses encompass a group of chronic fibrosing diseases of the lung resulting from 
exposure to organic and inorganic particulates, most commonly mineral dust.

questions.question: Question 12: What is the most common manifestation of asbestosis?
questions.explanation:
Pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen, often containing calcium. They develop 
most frequently on the parietal pleura and over the domes of the diaphragm. They do not contain 
asbestos bodies, and only rarely occur in persons without prior asbestos exposure. Asbestos occurs in two distinct forms - serpentine chrysotile (more common) 
and amphibole (more pathogenic). Exposure may result in the following conditions: • Localized fibrous plaques or, rarely, diffuse pleural fibrosis • Pleural effusions • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis) • Lung carcinoma • Mesotheliomas • Extrapulmonary neoplasms including laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas The image below shows fibrous pleural plaques seen on the diaphragmatic pleural surface in 
asbestosis. 1101 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy 
was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is: 1089 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing typical asbestos bodies are suggestive of asbestosis. Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing 
capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and 
solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis. Asbestos bodies are a typical finding. They are golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a 
translucent center. They consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous 
material and arise when these fibers are phagocytosed by macrophages. 1102 
Sold by @itachibot Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and are 
called ferruginous bodies.

Question 14: Patients A, B, and C presented to the OPD with symptoms of progressive dyspnea and cough. 
Further history and workup revealed the following findings. Who among them is more 
susceptible to developing tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Patient B is a worker in the sandblasting industry with eggshell calcification on x-ray. This is 
suggestive of silicosis. Patients with silicosis have a higher risk of tuberculosis as the crystalline 
silica impairs the ability of pulmonary macrophages to kill phagocytosed mycobacteria. The given clinical picture of patient A is classical of asbestosis and that of patient C is suggestive

Question 15: A 60-year-old man presented with dyspnea and cough. Chest X-ray revealed irregular linear 
densities, particularly in both lower lobes. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is 
shown below. This patient has a higher risk of developing: 1090 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows golden-brown, beaded rods with a translucent center called asbestos 
bodies which are seen in asbestosis. These patients are at risk of developing both lung 1103 
Sold by @itachibot carcinoma and mesothelioma. Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple 
asbestos bodies. Option A: Centrilobular emphysema may develop in simple coal workers' pneumoconiosis. Option B: Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis is seen in silicosis. Option C: Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and 
chemical dust (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, 
penicillin products).

questions.question:
Question 16: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of low-grade fever, dry cough, and progressive 
dyspnea. Examination reveals the following painless skin lesion. Chest X-ray shows bilateral 
hilar lymphadenopathy. Lung biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the 
following is not a feature of this condition? 1091 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Anergy to common skin test antigens

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the lesion of lupus pernio point towards 
sarcoidosis. It is a multisystemic disease characterized by polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous 
plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, 
telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating 
as lupus vulgaris. Immunological abnormalities include: • Polyclonal hyperglobulinemia • A CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5 • T- cell expansion and macrophage activation • Impaired dendritic cell function • Anergy to common skin tests. The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include: 1104 
Sold by @itachibot • B/L hilar lymphadenopathy • Non-caseating granulomas • Lupus pernio • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis) Syndromes associated with sarcoidosis are: • Mikulicz syndrome - sarcoidosis combined with uveoparotid involvement • Lofgren's syndrome - acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema 
nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma. The image below shows stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies that are found within giant 
cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas. 1105 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins known as 
Schaumann bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas. 1106 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: What is the most common gene mutation associated with pulmonary hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2) is the most common gene mutation 
in pulmonary hypertension. Inactivating mutations in this gene are found in 75% of the familial 
cases of pulmonary hypertension, and 25% of sporadic cases. The BMPR2 receptor is a cell surface protein belonging to the TGF- receptor superfamily. It is 
involved in the regulation of growth, differentiation, and apoptosis of pulmonary artery 
endothelial and smooth muscle cells. Due to the mutation, there is enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis of vascular 
endothelial and smooth muscle cells leading to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 57-year-old man presented with a persistent dry cough and progressive dyspnea. HRCT 
showed a crazy-paving pattern. Microscopy of BAL aspirate is shown below. Antibodies 
against which of the following are seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and microscopy showing alveoli filled with a dense, amorphous, protein-lipid 
granular precipitate are suggestive of autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). It is 
caused by circulating neutralizing antibodies specific for granulocyte-macrophage 
colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). 1107 
Sold by @itachibot PAP is a condition characterized by the accumulation of surfactants in alveoli and terminal 
airways. It can be due to impaired clearance or abnormal production of surfactants. PAP can be of three forms: • Primary (most common): There is impaired GM-CSF-dependent surfactant clearance by the 
alveolar macrophages. It can be due to: • Autoantibodies against GM-CSF (acquired/idiopathic/autoimmune PAP) • Mutation in GM-CSF receptors (hereditary PAP) • Secondary: There is a reduction in the number or ability of alveolar macrophages that causes 
impaired surfactant clearance. It can be due to: • Silicosis • Immunodeficiency disorders • Hematopoietic disorders and malignancies 1108 
Sold by @itachibot • Congenital: It affects neonates and children. There is abnormal surfactant production due to 
mutation in the genes coding for: • Surfactant protein B • Surfactant protein C • ATP binding cassette protein member 3

questions.question:
Question 20: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatiguability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed 
with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar 
lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment 
likely to be?
questions.explanation:
1109 
Sold by @itachibot The black-colored pigment in the hilar lymph node of the resected bronchoscopic specimen is 
likely to be an anthracotic pigment. The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are 
engulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes. 
This accumulates and causes the blackening of the lung tissues or anthracosis. It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with 
carbon particles, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in the 
human body as a result of air pollution in urban areas. The aggregates of the carbon dust may 
induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's 
pneumoconiosis. The following image shows anthracosis with deposition of black carbon particles, within the 
cytoplasm of macrophages. 1110 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Melanin is brown-black in color which occurs as a result of oxidation of tyrosine in 
melanocytes, as shown in the following histopathology of a lymph node. Option C: Lipochrome or lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen as a yellow-brown pigment in 
histopathological sections of the liver and heart of normal aging patients, patients with severe 
malnutrition, and cancer cachexia. It is derived through lipid peroxidation and indicates free 
radical injury and lipid peroxidation. The following image shows a cardiac myocyte with fine 
yellow-brown lipofuscin granules in the perinuclear region. 1111 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived golden-yellow colored pigment seen in conditions 
associated with iron overload such as hemochromatosis. The following image shows extensive 
intra-alveolar hemosiderin deposition following pulmonary hemorrhage. 1112 
Sold by @itachibot Lung tumors
